message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest diverticulitis, and abdominal CT can confirm the diagnosis with findings such as thickening or inflammation of the colon wall, abscess formation, or perforation. Lipase is a test for pancreatitis, and colonoscopy is not recommended in the acute phase of diverticulitis. Left lower quadrant ultrasound may not provide enough information for a definitive diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest acute diverticulitis, and abdominal CT is the most useful test for diagnosing this condition. Lipase is used to diagnose pancreatic disorders, left lower quadrant ultrasound would have limited diagnostic value, and emergent colonoscopy is not recommended in the acute setting of diverticulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of acute diverticulitis, which is commonly diagnosed by abdominal CT. Colonoscopy is not recommended in the acute setting and left lower quadrant ultrasound may not be sensitive enough to detect acute inflammation. Lipase levels are indicative of pancreatitis, which is not the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with left lower quadrant abdominal pain, heme-positive stool, and an elevated WBC count with left shift, indicating a possible diagnosis of diverticulitis. Abdominal CT scan is the most useful test for confirming the diagnosis of diverticulitis and evaluating the severity and extent of the disease. Lipase is used to evaluate for pancreatitis, left lower quadrant ultrasound may be helpful in evaluating for ovarian abnormalities in females, and colonoscopy is not indicated in the acute setting of diverticulitis.

Lipase level is helpful in diagnosing pancreatitis, left lower quadrant ultrasound can be used to evaluate ovarian cysts or renal stones, and emergent colonoscopy is not recommended in the acute phase of diverticulitis.

Abdominal CT can confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the disease. Lipase is used to diagnose pancreatitis, left lower quadrant ultrasound is not useful in diagnosing diverticulitis, and emergent colonoscopy is not indicated in the acute phase of diverticulitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with left lower quadrant pain, heme-positive stool, and elevated WBC count with left shift, suggesting the possibility of diverticulitis. Abdominal CT is the most useful test to confirm the diagnosis of diverticulitis and to assess the severity of the condition. Lipase measures pancreatic enzyme levels and is more helpful in diagnosing pancreatitis. Left lower quadrant ultrasound is not as sensitive or specific as abdominal CT for evaluating diverticulitis. Emergent colonoscopy is not recommended during an acute episode of diverticulitis due to the risk of perforation.

Lipase would be useful if pancreatitis were suspected, but it is not indicated in this case. Left lower quadrant ultrasound and emergent colonoscopy are not as sensitive or specific for the diagnosis of diverticulitis as abdominal CT.
